comment: It was fun back in the day, but it lost its luster.
Plenty of better party games these days.

1/5

terrible game. family weight for sure. hard to even call it a game.
Good luck if you aren't in on the inside jokes. There is no skill involved in this game.
Jolly for the first few times. Total non-gamers can have great fun unless/until they come to realize what a random waste of time this really is; a real non-game.
I am the #1 Party Pooper

I can't stand this game! You're all picking a random card from your hand that you think goes best with a description, and someone picks what card they think is the best/funniest. Okay fine, sounds like an activity to pass the time if nothing else is going on. Also, the game is supposed to have a winner (the person who has gotten luckiest and had their cards chosen the most) but that's just ridiculous. There's nothing you can do in this game to try and win.

Apples to Apples should be fun but there are few issues with it that seem to suck the fun out of it. It's meant to be a light party game but can take far too long to play as each player rambles on about why they chose their card.

I really don't want to spend more than 15 or 20 minutes playing a game like this and I'm counting each minute after that hoping it will end. The second biggest issue I have is that each player has to reveal which card they put in and then argue why it should be chosen only for the judge to choose someone else for a completely random reason. It means the arguments, which constitute most of the game are meaningless and the time spent arguing is wasted.

I much prefer the blind choice of Cards Against Humanity (even if that game is also poor for other reasons). Lastly the comedy just feels forced.
Unfortunately, I own this horrible game as a bad Christmas joke. If there's ever an apocalypse and I need fuel to make a fire, I'll keep this handy.

The worst "game" I have ever played. Not funny or clever, and not even a game. You simply put down a card hoping yours is selected. Some claim Apples to Apples teaches people how to predict other's responses, but it does no such thing. Dixit does what Apples to Apples claims to do, but is actually fun and clever. Buy Dixit instead. Apples to Apples is trash. How this is ranked better than Monopoly I will never know.
Party
Remove-bad game
I remember this being everywhere for a while, and looking back I still have no idea how anybody would ever enjoy it. How did this sell so many copies?

This should be in the dictionary as the definition of "Meh". This is a board game for those who don't play board games. It's simple, sure.... but the "fun" of this game stops after it's used as a cheap icebreaker. Every time I have played this game, everyone is so uninterested in the actual gameplay that half of the game is getting people to focus so they know when it's their turn. This game is the same amount of enjoyment as watching paint dry, with a group of your friends doing the same thing.
Not fun or a game.
bleh
Terrible in every way. I refuse to ever play this. I would rather sit and stare at the wall than play this.
Reminds me of my "LOL XD RANDOM :3" days on the internet, and I really do not want to go back there.
Just not my style of game. I will gladly bow out anytime this is offered up.
Waste of space it’s has little replay ability and zero strategy because you have zero clue when it ends
Best way to ruin a party.
I would give this a lower rating if I could. I will never play this again.

Although party games are not really about winning the scoring in this is far too frustrating to be much fun. Also, there is just no reason to play this when Dixit does the same thing better and with beautiful art.
5/18/15 (multiple plays before I logged much)

Democratic, not strategic. And, as was once said, the best argument against democracy is a five minute conversation with the average voter.

I guess technically only one person picks the winner but it's just banal banter beforehand. It's democratic in that there is a debate, and it's autocratic that an unelected bureaucrat will arbitrarily decide how each round goes.

This is not even a game; it is basically a corporate icebreaker/team-building exercise.

Its only redeeming feature is that you can quit at any time and it won't matter.

For a party game that actually involves some skill, I'd suggest Scattergories (though it requires reasonable people as there is still an evaluation phase).
BOOOOOOOOORING!!
Fun as a teenager, now it's just tedious.

Party activities more interestingly designed than this game:

Sit in complete silence.
Everyone go home and do your taxes.
Take turns punching each other in the face.

1\10 party filler, 10\10 party killer

I hate this game. The cards that win are consistently chosen for such ludicrous reasons that there is no real way to form a coherent strategy to win.
Potatoes aren't fascinating. Language is not purely subjective or we couldn't communicate.
If you want a game that has this mechanic, but actually is subjective, try Perfect Present. https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/32118/perfect-present
If you would like Tank better than a private chef, well, that's actually legitimately subjective.
I hate this "game." This is also responsible for starting the judging phenomenon that I generally despise.
how do people enjoy this "game"?
P.G. cards against humanity. Doesn't make the game any more fun or hilarious.
I hate this game.
Didn´t Like it at all. Forgettable.

Simple party game that could be a lot of fun with the right group. It also can come off the rails and feel like an exercise in futility when playing with one or more people that frown on off-the-wall and humorous plays.

I don't understand how anyone like this game. Complete garbage. The social dynamics of Apples to Apples are roughly those of a sold-out Greyhound bus stuck in stop-and-go traffic. If you're at a party and people start playing "Apples to apples," leave. Don't say goodbye, these people are not your friends, just leave.
I overplayed it in college when it was new.
the worst, and even worse with people who take it too seriously.

More of a social activity than a game. It gives way too much power to the whims of whoever is the judge to the point that it always ends up feeling completely random.

You may as well just take turns turning up the top red and green card to the middle of the table and discuss the implications of how they match. In fact, that would be more entertaining since it wouldn't be pretending to be a game.
Terrible kingmaking party game.

If I could give this abomination of a game a 0 rating, I would. It's a random collection of cards to be played at random and hope for the best to randomly happen. Seriously, that is as valid a strategy as any. Did I mention this "game" is entirely random? Awful. Makes me want to stab my eyes out with a fork, because that would feel heavenly compared to sitting through a game of Apples to Apples.
Not a game and also stupid.
Ugh.
There is no game here.
It's Apple to Apples. What more is there to say? The experience is highly dependent on the group you play with and whether they want serious or funny answers.
Please. No. Just stop pulling this thing out at parties. Please.
The stated object of this game is way different from what the gameplay actually degenerates into. An exercise in futility.

This game always starts fun, but within about 5-10 minutes someone gets bored and then just starts picking random cards. Example: Card to match "Historical Figure", cards that come in Abraham Lincoln, Caesar, Hitler and Chocolate. And the bored person will pick Chocolate.
Embarrassed to even own this, but it was a gift, yuck! Dusty as hell and I don't give a damn. Keep waiting for something to catch on fire so I can use this to put it out with!
so boring. why do people insist on playing it?

A very bad game. It is so subjective that even if you have a card that is accurate or correct the judge can still pick something stupid or not even related (apples to oranges should be the title).

DEFINITELY a game for non-gamers that are mentally challenged and like wasting their time on garbage.
Upon review, I was too nice to this.

While party games are never my first choice, I am perfectly happy to play a game like Balderdash, Dixit, Crappy Birthday, or even (if the circumstances are right) Pictionary.

Apples to Apples is like a vampire that attacked those other games and sucked all of the fun right out of them. It forces the players into making choices which do not allow for any creativity whatsoever. The result is an experience which is boring and generally not fun.

I hesitate even to call this a game, The random and arbitrary nature in which a player wins makes it impossible to strategize on any level.

Reading the scathing comments on BGG is much more fun than playing the game itself.
I cannot express how much I loath this game.

I wouldn't normally give a game a crazy low rating like this, but the avg rating for this game won't suffer on my account. The title of this game are the three words I most fear when going to a party where there will be "games". I can see why some people like it with the right crowd, just not my cup of tea.

Infuriating game IMO. Everybody else loves it, it just rubs me the wrong way.

After further analysis, I think my initial impression had something to do with the group I've played it with.

Nope, played it with a better group and it's still boring and tedious. Sorry A2A, The Big Bang Theory party game just did your shtick right, so your rating dropped back down to where it was initially.
Uh, where is the 'game' in this game?
Just not really a game in my opinion, but it can be fun to play during a party with the right people.

I never want to play this again. It wasn't remotely fun. Even if I logically have the best card someone won't pick it because they don't know or they like star wars and will pick darth vader. Terrible game. If you ask me to play it I might accidently destroy it.
The winner is 80% arbitrary. Not my kind of game at all.

I absolutley hate this game. I used to think I liked it, back when I could combine cards such as "Helen Keller" and "Touchy Feely." However, once that novelty wore off this game had nothing left to offer.

The thing that really takes any enjoyment straight out of the game is the whole "you gotta play your opponent" idea. EEEEFFFFFF that noise. So stupid. Your telling me that if I want to win I shouldn't play the card that everyone thinks is funny just because its the prudish boring guys turn and he's likely to pick something "realistic?" Awful.

Please God replace every copy of this game with Dixit.
I absolutely hate this thing. I can't call it a game, because it isn't one. It is more a torture device than a game.
Tried inputting 0 and 0.0000001 as my rating for this terrible game

The outcome of this game is completely subjective to the whim of the shallow group that plays it.

If you are playing against a group of people that are at all interested in winning or being "serious" there is no strategy or way to beat them fast just to get the game over with. As the ego-centrists drag the game ad nauseum, you'll feel yourself being dragged into a nonobjective black hole of stupidity.
If you find yourself lucky enough to play with an agreeable group, you're better off just having a nice conversation with them.

Similar (but much better, more logical and non-subjective) alternatives would include Scattergories, Balderdash.... or even calvinball

Furthermore, this game contains no useful bits to cannibalize towards making something useful. The cards were cheaply printed, and since thats the only thing besides the box itself, its nearly worthless.

I would have rated this game a zero, but it gets a bonus point for resale value or if you feel like doing the human race a favor its possible to take it completely out of circulation by re-skinning the box and putting another game inside after discarding the previous contents.

Horrible, horrible, horrible party game. I don't hate all party games, but I do hate this one. Boring and repetitive it seems like each turn is the exact same, which wouldn't be bad.....if the turns were actually fun.

Would be better if each person just had a pencil and paper and could make up words rather than being limited to a particular hand of cards.....but then, why would you even need a game for that ?
1 play. This is only very loosely a "game"--more like a social experiment.

Awful.

I particularly like party games. The minimum that a party game should do is inspire creativity, This one does the opposite -- rarely anyone finds strange word combinations amusing. So the game becomes about being the lucky player to have the most bland noun card at the right time.

For word association games, Scattergories beats this easily.

Cute party game to play once and then its novelty wears off. It's very much a no brainer and unless you have some hilariously funny people it will be a big yawner. Played this game once out of choice, then was forced to play it 4 more times now it's on the blacklist. Not sure why so many folks are enamored with it. Its one advantage is it accommodates a lot of people.

Shocking update: Apples to Apples becomes absolutely fantastic when you spend a bunch of time beforehand making personalized noun cards. The better the members of the group know each other, the better. This change turns Apples to Apples into a solid '8' or '9' from its usual miserable '1.' Original (and still relevant) comment below.

----------

I can't remember the last time I played a game this bad. Deciding whether 'Martha Stewart' or 'San Andreas Fault' is more 'easy' is not funny. I would rather play Duck Duck Goose.

The very best party games are essentially environments that foster creativity in all participants--creativity, in many cases, the players don't even believe they have. These games tend to be parlor games (Celebrities being the best example, really), because when the players determine all the content (names in Celebrities, whatevers in Charades or even 20 Questions, etc.), everyone can feel a sense of 'ownership' over the game. That is to say, each game of 20 Questions will have its own special dynamic created entirely by the players within the very simple framework. Time's Up, the commercial release of the near-perfect parlor game Celebrities, comes with a deck of celebrities' names that are to be used. Nothing could be worse.

Well, except for Apples to Apples. In this title, players' ownership over the course of the game is taken from them entirely and put into a deck of cards they had no control in creating. "Gameplay" consists of assembling the cards together, and presumably laughing about how inappropriate the card pairings sometimes were. This is depressing!

How this game ever became as popular as it did is a giant mystery to me. For people to say that it's a "non-gamer" game or a party-game is absurd. It's just a BAD game. I have no idea how anyone can play this game. If Jesus Christ Himself came down from on high and asked me to play a game, I'd have to think long and hard about it. This game is the epitome of the word interminable. You want a party game? Play Balderdash or even Trivial Pursuit, but leave this one where it belongs: as far away as possible.
There are some great party games out there. This isn't one of them. I'd rather just talk with the people I'm with than play this game. It's just no fun at all.

As you may have noticed from my rating (1), I do not like this activity. I refrain from calling it a "game" because the judge has supreme control in their criterion for picking a card, eliminating any game rules and theory, and can be capricious and arbitrary.

Perhaps I have not played this with sufficiently serious players, but in all my plays (involving mid-school aged and family members) the game has simply degenerated to the judge picking the funniest word arbitrarily. There is no way to predict, strategize, or otherwise "game" the decision. The only benifit to this supposed game (that I have seen) is its educational aspect when a younger player does not understand a specific word or term on the cards.

Apples to Apples holds as much excitement for me as a pack of mid-school flash cards!
after about five plays this game gets real old, real quick. If I never see this game pulled out at a party I will be happy.
Less of a game, more of an event.

I do not understand this "game".

UPDATE: From a geeklist, on suggested strategy (to get others to never pull this game out again) is to always announce that you will be playing your cards in order, and do so. Awesome.
Horrible. 0-1

The "game" is one of predicting the other players mental connections while being constrained by a random selection of cards. In theory, this might work, but you would really have to know the other people well. If you don't the other players well, they might as well be random. I think we are all supposed to laugh at the various connections. In practice, the "game" is seemingly random and it's boring.

l thoughtfully took a homemade Disney-theme version of Hollywood Blockbuster to L.A. in the hopes my girlfriend's friends we were staying with would enjoy this game that was perfectly themed for our visit. Come game night, they opted instead for Apples to Apples -- "even less thinking than Taboo", the hostess tittered. The only highlight of that game was my playing an unaltered blank card for "Frivolous (trivial, silly, shallow)", saying the answer was already written on the back of the card. In the end, an overly-long session of unfunny randomness. Because of this letdown, I now refuse to ever play Apples to Apples again.
I truly loathe this game. Boring as hell.

FYI - This is not a game. It is a system to, as Monty Pyhton once put, "to buy a conversation."

If you want to play a game, play a game. If you want a conversation, have one. Apples to Apples is abysmal.
I feel that calling this a game is unfair. It is a method of entertainment to use at a party, in a way not dissimilar from morton's list. Judged as a game, it fails horribly.
Hand Management / Simultaneous Selection / Voting
this sort of game is like conversation, but for people who are incapable of having their own ideas. In that way, it makes perfect sense for children and for the foolish amongst us
Present from a well-meaning relative. ("You like board games-so I bought you one!")

Can be loads of fun with the right group, but this is the game kids usually point at when I ask what they want to play, and it can be pretty boring with a bunch of kids who don't know who any of the people (or events and things) in the game are.
There are just so many better party games. Pass.
Was innovative, but not anymore. Thing is, the game is fun when some good, funny combinations come up, and the random card draw limits that a lot: too few good moments, limited by the game system.
Not a fan.
Sometimes mildly amusing. That's about the nicest thing I can say.
Incredibly boring, and now there are much more fun variations out there.
4-10 players 30 minutes

The game that existed before Cards Against Humanity. I've played this when I've gamed with children before, and it's ok in that regard. Why play this though when you can play Cards Against humanity instead.
hate this game
Ugh! Mimics the type of game I think is utter tripe.
I don't like games where you just make up a lot of the rules. In this case, the rules have it so that players make up the winning answers. This is not so much a game and more of an activity.
Family friendly meh...
The OG game of picking the funniest option. Played a lot in middle school, but not something I would chose now.
I find this game tiresome.
A lot of downtime, not a lot of player choice, not a lot of opportunities for table talk. Unfortunately, my friends love this game.

The game claims to be hilarious but we were bored to tears. Rarely, if ever, was anything played ever actually laugh out loud funny. At -best- some were mildly amusing, but it took MAJOR effort on my part to get my kids to even crack a smile as we played this. I thought it might be better at the junior level so I bought that one at the thrift store too, but it was just as awful.

Not really into party games all that much so this one bores me terribly.

The only flaw this game has is that it's mind-numbingly boring. I have had a few decent times with it, but never a good time. It's less offensive than Cards Against Humanity, but I have at least had more raucous times with that, despite all its flaws. Do yourself a favor and never play this.
A novelty the first time you play it. Then, the joke wears off quickly. I would say the same of all of its imitators.

This game is so boring you have basicly no decisions to make, look at your cards pick the one the makes the most sence put it in the pile repeat and try to not fall asleep. This game is popular because most people have no creativity so it let's them play a party game that feels like you made a funny smart decision but you actually did nothing. The fact that everyone outside of the hobby always wants to play this or cards against humanity makes me rate it lower
Party game that doesn't feel like a party.
Overplayed, stale party game.

We were given a tip on a great game called Apples to Apples. We went to the store and bought it, not only did we buy the game we bought the boxed edition with all the expansions. Excited we took it to our friends house and played it. We played it 5 times. No one had fun and so we put it on the shelf. To this day when I think of a game that completely blows I think of Apples to Apples.

I appreciate it was important when it came out (hence why I owned a copy) as it got the whole 'party game' ball really rolling, but it's barely a game.

When played as per the rules, it's just an exercise in 'what appeals to my friends'? It's like having a conversation where you don't talk and instead play cards.

Vastly improved by a house variant where each player must explain why they picked their chosen card. The attempt to justify clearly disparate concepts is often hilarious. But I'd still rather play almost any other game.
terrible random "game"
Can be funny. Most rounds are not. There is a nice element of figuring out what different players like and will choose as the winner. Other than that, the cards are pretty mediocre.
This style of game just isn't fun for me.
Yea whatever. Fun if you’re in middle school and none of your friends are creative.

(11/15) 3.

(10/17) Drop to 2. Maybe I didn't play this early enough but it just seems so very bland. I can't think of many, if any, games I wouldn't rather play.

I don't know, I removed the outer wrap but left the cards sealed, meh. I see no humor or fun to be had here.

Destroyer of Parties.
Good classic party game. We've had some fun with this game.

Scoring is both subjective and pointless. The actual gameplay is at the whim of whoever is judging and what cards you draw. Slightly more thought required than CAH, but not enough to make me actually want to play this again.

Bad Game! People use experiences to inform decisions, which is fine as long as you were a part of those experiences. But, when people pick answers because of their friend from 1st grade who made them laugh and this card just reminded them of that time, it makes for a mind-numbing experience. Plus, several times your cards just don't fit the description. Both of these make it so too often you are randomly throwing cards down, and mostly because you just want a better card than that even though it has almost nothing to do with the description. What's worse: sometimes your throw away card gets picked!!!!??????

The wife likes it. I just don't get it. Super lame. There's no real room to be creative since you're given the cards. I would much rather play something like Taboo or Five Second Rule in a party situation.

The most fun I ever had with this game was only using the adjective cards. My sister and I would flip over a card and then each of us would try to convince the other why that adjective described us more than the other person - regardless of what it was. Way more fun than the real game.
Fun only if the other players are having fun too. Kind of obnoxious to have the "picker" choosing cards that have not one ounce of similarity to the topic card.

If you are into social party games for gateway and lightweight gamers I can think of a number of titles that have replaced this - Codenames, Dixit, and Anomia all spring to mind immediately. For me this falls in the same category as activities like Cards Against Humanity - a chance to hang out but not really a game.

Super bad.

This game.... is not a game. This is "Hey everybody, is my card the best?"

Maybe it's because my competitive nature won't let me play a game "just for fun" or maybe it's because I always think people choose the wrong answer, but I get annoyed just thinking about this game. If I'm gonna play an opinion-based game I'll play Cards Against Humanity any day over this because at least I get some laughs from CaH.

When this first came out - I LOVED it. Then I played it 500 times and each time I played it I hated it more and more. I guess I'm just not funny enough to play this game, since my family and friends always want the most hilarious answer. I actually think I have a different sense of humor than most people, so that's probably it. Won't play again unless someone REALLY begs me to. And pays me money. I do not understand why this game is popular.
no.

I do not find this game fun or funny. I suppose I would play it with kids, but for a similar type of experience I would rather play Cards Against Humanity (with adults).

If not played by the right people, can be un-fun. We had one person who took all the responses and just picked one arbitrarily without trying to get close to the original choice at all. It made us all feel like we were just wasting our time.

This is routinely a hit with non-gamers for me and in that context I am somewhat willing to play (if they really won't play anything else). But this is a PURELY content-driven game, so while it might be funny the first time around all of the humor literally evaporates once you've seen the cards and combinations a couple times. Give me something with actual creativity any day.

Attribute has the same concept but is much funnier and has better longevity thanks to actual player input and the match/mismatch idea to add variety, but unfortunately its fiddly scoring system and minor dexterity element can turn some people (especially non-gamers) off.
Fun party game if you have some knowledge of the individuals... In great shape.

One of the first games I ever played, first let me tell you that I love party games, but not this one. At first I thought this was almost fun, but I dislike Apples to Apples. The game is completely random; you have no way to control your victory. Winning depends on the mood of the judges, if you could write anything down as an answer the game would be better, but you are limited by your cards. If you want a party game go play Dixit or Time´s Up, both very superior games.

I give AtA a lot of credit for the idea of a “judge” party game. It’s not really for me because it feels to random (e.g. I’ll get points on words that didn’t feel like they were that good and vice versa). But 20 years ago sure I’d play it if everyone else wanted to because it was the only judge game out there. Today there’s scores of them and most all of them have a specific theme that make it funnier or more entertaining over AtA, which is mostly a victim of those standing on its shoulders.

I gave this a 1, because I honestly feel that this game is broken. Someone will submit a card that 5 out of the 6 people playing will agree is the best possible match, but the 6th person is the "judge" and he won't pick that card because
a: he doesn't understand what that card means (or he doesn't know who it is)
b: he decides it would be "funny" to pick the card that is the worst possible match
c: he tries to read people's facial expressions when the cards are read so he can pick the person he likes

So basically since this game relies on being subjective it is broken. Also, when I criticize the game, people who like the game make this claim - "If you're playing to win you're playing it wrong" Doesn't that mean it's not a game?

Even then, I will probably choose other games over Apples to Apples, despite its universal appeal, especially since it often falls into the "How can I tailor my red cards played to what the other person finds funny," rather than trying to play a red card that is most appropriate for the judge's chosen green card.

Clunky game, with potential for some, often forced, laughs
-This game is incredibly simple to learn (literally a one minute explanation). Pick a green card containing an adjective -> everyone picks a red card from their hand that matches the green card in the funniest way possible -> person that picked the green card chooses whose is the funniest -> next person chooses green card.
-The exclusive goal in the game is to be the funniest with your card choices. While this may sound exciting, it comes across as being forced and arbitrary. There are much better games that naturally produce funny scenarios and often laughter (as well as a range of other emotions), and these games are often more memorable.
-If you are looking for a game promising laughs -- I would look into a dexterity game (eg. flipships), a party game (eg. skull, codenames), or a heavily thematic game (mysterium, galaxy trucker).

Before there was Cards Against Humanity (and every other flavor of matching game), there was Apples to Apples. Folks will prefer one or another such game based upon the tone they want, but for my money, this game remains a solid entry into the field. It won't be my favorite, but it will always satisfy, and it seems to appeal to more people than most others.

It's simple: Everyone gets a hand of 7 cards, and one person, on a rotating basis, serves as just for a round. The judge selects a red apple card, reads it aloud, and waits for the others to submit their green apple cards. The judge shuffles them and lays them out to decide which is best/funniest/rudest/whateveryoudecidest. The players may, of course, lobby for their choice (whether theirs or anyone else's). There are the usual variants, of course, for playing two cards to playing antonyms, and more.

Set up and re-boxing are minimal, as you take cards out, shuffle them, deal them, and start on one side, and that's the slower of the two.

Nice get to know you game. I actually like the kids game Grounded for Life better, it's a bit sillier. But this game can get silly too. You have a couple ways to play and strategize. 20+ years after its initial release, AtA has gotten a second lease on life in our house - especially during family visits and holidays. Still fun, though players should be able to discard and replace outdated/unfamiliar words at will.

The game out of the box is a 4.5.

I created a house ruled version that makes the game an 8+.

All I did was add a scoring system, which added strategy, and took out bias:

The players all choose one of their 7 cards to give to the judge. Those cards are shuffled before being seen by the judge so that no bias is created.

Then the judge will give out its first score. It could be the best answer, worst answer, or most middle answer. Note that no players are allowed to say ANYTHING about the answers. The judge makes their first decision with their gut and own intuition. That player will receive points based on number of players. Points are kept secret. (We use clay poker chip counters to keep score. The players keep the counters hidden.)

The player who scored can now help the judge make future decisions. They can give their opinions. The judge takes those into consideration, but doesn't have to follow what they say at all. Usually, the judge will at least acknowledge the thoughts of the already scored players.

Then the judge gives out the next score and so on and so forth.

Ex. When there are 2 people left, everyone else will be able to give the judge their thoughts.

With scoring, it's best to have everyone getting a different score with a bit more weight to the front and back ends.

Here's how I score for player counts:
4: -1, 0, 1, 3
5: -1, 0, 1, 2, 4
6: -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 5
7+…

You just follow that pattern of scoring.
The negative 1 really makes it exciting.
I'd recommend keeping that in.

This game is similar to Cards Against Humanity, but is a family friendly version. I have loads of sealed taster packs for sale and invented my own additional rules for this in order to extend the game play life of the cards. Packs are for sale (including additional rules) at £3.99 each. Customers can buy in bulk for £2.99 per pack (for 10 or more) £1.99 per pack (for 50 or more) or £0.99 per pack (100 or more). Ideal for playing parties (as an ice breaker game), party bags, wedding gift bags, for use as a travel game, or giving as a complimentary gift e.g. as prizes at board game evenings etc. All the packs are the same and have 40 red apple cards, 5 green apple cards and quick play rules.

Don't listen to the haters. In some ways, this is the best game of all time. This is the perfect game for non-gamers, and if you bring the right cards and the right attitude, even a Eurogamer, Wargamer, or Ameritrash enthusiast can enjoy this. You have to accept that you can't control your fate; the winner is 99% random, but deciding which card to play for each round is hilarious and fun. This game should be a part of anyone's collection.
